div2.head: Scene One
div2.stage: Enter Gaveston reading on a letter that was brought him from the king.

l.q: My father is deceast, come Gaveston,
And share the kingdom with thy deerest friend .

sp.l: Ah words that make me surfet with delight:
What greater blisse can hap to Gaveston,
Then live and be the favorit of a king?
Sweete prince I come, these these these thy amorous lines,
Might have enforst me to have swum swam from France,
And like Leander gaspt upon the sande,
So thou wouldst smile and take me in thy thine armes.
The sight of London to my mine exiled eyes,
Is as Elizium Elizium to a new come soule . ,
Not that I love the citie or the men,
But that it harbors him I hold so deare,
The king, upon whose bosome let me die lie ,
And with the world be still at enmitie:
What neede the artick people love star-light,
To whom the sunne shines both by day and night.
Farewell base stooping to the lordly peeres,
My knee knees shall bowe to none but to the king . ,
As Its for the multitude that they are but sparkes,
Rakt Bakt up in embers of their povertie,
Tanti tantam : Ile fawne fanne Q1-4, Dd1-2, S, Ch, Dd3, Bgs, first on the winde,
That glaunceth at my lips and flieth away:
But how now, what are these?
Such Poor men, such as desire your your your worships service.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: What canst thou doe?

sp.speaker: 1. poore man
sp.l: I can ride.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: But I have no horses horse . What art thou?

sp.speaker: 2. poore man
sp.l: A traveller.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: Let me see, thou wouldst do well

To waite at my trencher, and tell me lies at dinner time
,
And as I like your discoursing, ile have you.
And what art thou?

sp.speaker: 3. poore man
sp.l: A souldier, that hath serv'd against the Scot.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: Why there are hospitals for such as you,
I have no warre, and therefore sir be gone.
Farewell, and perish by a souldiers hand,
That wouldst reward them with an hospitall.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: I, I, these wordes of his move me as much,
As if a Goose should would play the Porpintine Porcupine ,
And dart eate her plumes, thinking to pierce my brest,
But yet it is no paine to speake men faire,
Ile flatter these them , and make them live in hope:
You know that I came lately out of France,
And yet I have not viewd my Lord the king,
If I speed well, ile entertaine you all.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: We thanke your worship.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: I have some busines, leave me to my selfe.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: We I will wait heere about the court.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: Do: these are not men for me,
I must have wanton Poets, pleasant wits,
Musitians, that with touching of a string
May draw the pliant king which way I please:
Musicke and poetrie is are his delight,
Therefore ile have Italian maskes by night,
Sweete speeches, comedies, and pleasing showes,
And in the day when he shall walke abroad,
Like Sylvian Sylvan Nimphes my pages shall be clad,
My men like Satyres grazing gasing on the lawnes,
Shall with their Goate Goates feete daunce an the antick hay . ,
Sometime Sometimes Dd1- a lovelie boye in Dians shape,
With haire that gilds the water as it glides,
Crownets of pearle about his naked armes,
And in his sportfull hands an Olive tree,
To hide those parts which as men delight to see,

Shall bathe him in a spring, and there hard
by,
One like Actaeon peeping through the grove,
Shall by the angrie goddesse be transformde,
And running in the likenes of an Hart,
By yelping hounds puld downe, and shall seeme to die . ,
Such things as these best please his majestie , .

My lord. Heere comes the king and here and
the nobles nobles
From the parlament, ile stand aside.

div2.stage:
Enter the King,
Lancaster
, Mortimer senior, Mortimer junior, Edmund Earle of Kent, Guie Earle of
Warwicke
, &c.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: My Lorde.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l:
That Earle of
Lancaster
do I abhorre.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l:
Will you not graunt me this? —
In spight of them[Aside.]
Ile have my will, and these two Mortimers,
That crosse me thus, shall know I am displeasd.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: If you love us my lord, hate Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: That villaine Mortimer, ile be his death.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Mine unckle heere, this Earle, and I my selfe,
Were sworne to unto Dd1- your father at his death,
That he should nere returne into the realme:
And know my lord, ere I will breake my oath,
This sword of mine that should offend your foes,
Shall sleepe within the scabberd at thy neede,
And underneath thy banners march who will,
For Mortimer will hang his armor up.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Well Mortimer, ile make thee rue these words,
Beseemes it thee to contradict thy king?

Frownst thou thereat ,
aspiring Lancaster,
The sworde shall plane plaine the furrowes of thy browes,
And hew these knees that now are growne so stiffe . ,
I will have Gaveston, and you shall know,
What danger tis to stand against your king.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: Well doone, Ned.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: My lord, why do you thus incense your peeres,
That naturally would love and honour you , :
But for that base and obscure Gaveston : ,
Foure Earldomes have I besides Lancaster,

Darbie,
Salsburie,
Lincolne,
Leicester,
These will I sell to give my souldiers paye,
Ere Gaveston shall stay within the realme . ,
Therefore if he be come, expell him straight.
Barons and Earls, your pride hath made me mute n ,
But now ile speake, and to the proofe I hope:
I do remember in my fathers dayes,
Lord Percie Peirce of the North being highly mov'd,
Brav'd Mowberie in presence of the king,
For which, had not his highnes lov'd him well,
He should have lost his head, but with his looke,
The undaunted spirit of Percie was appeasd,
And Mowberie and he were reconcild:
Yet dare you brave the king unto his face . ,
Brother revenge it, and let these their heads,
Preach Perch upon poles for trespasse of their tongues.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: O our heads ? .

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: I yours, and therefore I would wish you graunt.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: Bridle thy anger gentle Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: I cannot, nor I will not, I must speake . ,
Cosin, our hands I hope shall fence our heads,
And strike off his that makes you threaten us.
Come unckle, let us leave the this brainsick king,
And henceforth parle with our naked swords.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: Wilshire hath men enough to save our heads.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: All Warwickshire will love leave him for my sake.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: And Northward Gaveston Lancaster hath many friends . ,
Adew my Lord, and either change your minde,
Or looke to see the throne where you should sit,
To floate in bloud, and at thy wanton head,
The glozing head of thy base minion throwne.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: I cannot brooke these hautie menaces:
Am And I a king and must be over rulde?
Brother displaie my ensignes in the field,
Ile bandie with the Barons and the Earles,
And eyther die, or live with Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: I can no longer keepe me from my lord.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: What Gaveston, welcome: kis nay, kiss not my hand,
Embrace me Gaveston as I do thee:

Why shouldst thou kneele,
knowest thou not who I am?
Thy friend, thy selfe, another Gaveston . ,
Not Hilas was more mourned of for for of by Hercules,
Then thou hast beene of me since thy exile.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: And since I went from hence, no soule in hell
Hath felt more torment then poore Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: I know it, brother welcome home my friend . ,
Now let the treacherous Mortimers conspire,
And that high minded earle of Lancaster,
I have my wish, in that I joy thy sight,

And sooner shall the sea orewhelme overwhelme
my the land,
Then beare the ship that shall transport thee hence:
I heere create thee the Lord high Chamberlaine,
Cheefe Secretarie to the state and me,
Earle of Cornewall, king and lord of Man.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: My lord, these titles far exceed my worth.
Brother, the least of these may well suffice
For one of greater birth then Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Cease brother, for I cannot brooke these words : ,
Thy woorth sweet friend is far above my guifts,
Therefore to equall it receive my hart . ,
If for these dignities thou be envied should'st be envied envied be ,
Ile give thee more, for but to honour thee,
Is Edward pleazd with kinglie regiment.
Fearst thou thy person? thou shalt have a guard:
Wants thou gold? go to my treasurie : , .
Wouldst thou be lovde and fearde? receive my seale seals ,
Save or condemne, and in our name commaund,
What so Whate'er thy minde affectes or fancie likes.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: It shall suffice me to enjoy your love,
Which whiles I have, I thinke my selfe as great,
As Caesar riding in the Romaine streete streets ,
With captive kings at his triumphant Carre.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l:
whether whither goes my Lord of
Coventrie
so fast?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: To celebrate your fathers exequies,
But is that wicked Gaveston returnd?

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: I priest, and lives to be revengd on thee,
That wert the onely cause of his exile.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: Tis true, and but for reverence of these those robes,
Thou shouldst not plod one foote beyond this place.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: I did no more then I was bound to do,
And Gaveston unlesse thou be reclaimd,
As then I did incense the parlement,
So will I now, and thou shalt back to France.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: Saving your reverence, you must pardon me.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Throwe of his golden miter, rend his stole,
And in the channell christen him a new.
Ah brother, lay not violent valiant hands on him,

For heele complaine unto the sea of
Rome
.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: Let him complaine unto the sea of hell,
Ile be revengd on him for my exile.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: No Well , spare his life, but seaze upon his goods,
Be thou lord bishop, and receive his rents,
And make him serve thee as thy chaplaine,
I give him thee, here use him as thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: He shall to prison, and there die in boults.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l:
I ,
to the tower, the fleete, or where thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: For this offence be thou accurst of God.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Whose there? conveie this priest to unto the tower.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: True, true Do, do Prut, prut Tut, tut .

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: But in the meane time Gaveston away,
And take possession of his house and goods : ,
Come follow me, and thou shalt have my guarde,
To see it done, and bring thee safe againe.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: What should a priest do with so faire a house?

div2.head: Act One, Scene Two
div2.stage:
Enter both the Mortimers,
Warwicke
, and
Lancaster
.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: Tis true, the Bishop is in the tower,
And goods and body given to Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: What? will they tyrannize upon the Church?
Ah wicked king, accurssed Gaveston,
This ground which is corrupted with their steps,
Shall be their timeles sepulcher, or mine.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Lancaster
Wel, let that peevish Frenchman guard him sure ,
Unlesse his brest be sword proofe he shall die.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l:
How now, why droops the earle of
Lancaster
?

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l:
Wherfore is Guy of
Warwicke
discontent?

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: That villaine Gaveston is made an Earle.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: An Earle!

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: I, and besides, lord Chamberlaine of the realme,
And secretary to, and lord of Man.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: We may not, nor we will not suffer this. Mortimer.
Why post we not from hence to levie men?

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l:
My lord of Cornewall
, now ,
at every worde,
And happie is the man, whom he vouchsafes
For vailing of his bonnet one good looke . ,
Thus arme in arme, the king and he dooth do To To marche:
Nay more, the guarde upon his lordship waites:
And all the court begins to flatter him.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: Thus leaning on the shoulder of the king,
He nods, and scornes, and smiles at those that passe.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: Doth no man take exceptions exception at the slave?

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: All stomack him, but none dare speake a word.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Ah Ay that bewraies their basenes Lancaster,
Were all the Earles and Barons of my minde,
Weele We'd Weeld hale him from the bosome of the king,
And at the court gate hang the pessant up,
Who swolne with venome of ambitious pride,
Will be the ruine of the realme and us.

div2.stage: Enter the [Arch] Bishop of Canterburie [and attendant].

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l:
Here comes my lord of
Canterburies
grace.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: His countenance bewraies he is displeasd.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: First were his sacred garments rent and torne,
Then laide they violent hands upon him, next ,
Himselfe imprisoned, and his goods asceasd,
This certifie the Pope, away , Q1 take horsse.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: My lord, will you take armes against the king?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: What neede I, God himselfe is up in armes,
When violence is offered to the church.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Then wil you joine with us that be his peeres
To banish or behead that Gaveston?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: What els my lords, for it concernes me neere,

The Bishoprick of
Coventrie
is his.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l:
Madam,
whether whither
whither walks your majestie so fast?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Unto the forrest gentle Mortimer,
To live in greefe and balefull discontent,
For now my lord the king regardes me not,
But dotes upon the love of Gaveston . ,
He claps his cheekes cheek , and hanges about his neck,
Smiles in his face, and whispers in his eares,
And when I come, he frownes, as who should say,

Go
whether whither
whither thou wilt seeing I have Gaveston Gaveston .

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: Is it not straunge, that he is thus bewitcht?

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Madam, returne unto the court againe:
That slie inveigling Frenchman weele exile,
Or lose our lives: and yet ere that day come,
The king shall lose his crowne, for we have power,
And courage to, to be revengde at full.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: But yet lift not your swords against the king.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: No, but weele we will Coll lift Gaveston that Gaveston from hence.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: And war must be the meanes, or heele stay stil.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Then let him stay, for rather then my lord
Shall be opprest by with civill mutinies,
I wil endure a melancholie life,
And let him frollick with his minion.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: My lords, to eaze all this, but heare me speake . ,
We and the rest that are his counsellers,
Will meete, and with a generall consent,
Confirme his banishment with our handes and seales.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: What we confirme the king will frustrate.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Then may we lawfully revolt from him.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: But say my lord, where shall this meeting bee?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: At the new temple.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Content . :

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: And in the meane time ile intreat you all,
To crosse to Lambeth, and there stay with me.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: Come then lets away.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Madam farewell.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Farewell sweet Mortimer, and for my sake,
Forbeare to levie armes against the king.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: I Ah , if words will serve, if not, I must.

div2.head: Act One, Scene Three
div2.stage: Enter Gaveston and the earle ofKent.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l:
Edmund ,
the mightie prince of Lancaster ,
That hath more earldomes then an asse can beare,

And both the Mortimers ,
two goodly men,
With Guie of Warwick that redoubted knight,
Are gone towards Lambeth, there let them remaine.

div2.head: Act One, Scene Four
div2.stage:
Enter Nobiles [: Lancaster,
Warwicke
, Penbrooke, Mortimer senior, Mortimer junior, the Archbishop of Canterburie, attended].

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: Here is the forme of Gavestons exile:
May it please your lordship to subscribe your name.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Give me the paper.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l:
Quick quick my lorde,
I long to write my name.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: But I long more to see him banisht hence.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: The name of Mortimer shall fright the king,
Unlesse he be declinde from that base pesant.

div2.stage: Enter the King and Gaveston [and Kent].

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: What? are you mov'd that Gaveston sits heere?
It is our pleasure, we and we will have it so.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: Your grace doth wel to place him by your side,
For no where else the new earle is so safe.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: What man of noble birth can brooke this sight?
See what a scornfull looke the pesant casts.

sp.speaker: Penbrooke
sp.l: Can kinglie Lions fawne on creeping Ants?

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: Ignoble vassaile that like Phaeton,
Aspir'st unto the guidance of the sunne.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Their downfall is at hand, their forces downe,
We will not thus be facst and overpeerd.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Lay hands on that traitor Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: Lay hands on that traitor Gaveston.
Is this the dutie that you owe your king?

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: We know our duties, let him know his peeres.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l:
whether whither
whither will you beare him, stay or ye shall die.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: We are no traitors, therefore threaten not.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: No, threaten not my lord, but pay them home.
Were I a king-- . -

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Thou villaine, wherfore talkes thou of a king,
That hardly art a gentleman by birth?

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l:
Were he a peasant ,
being my minion,
Ile make the prowdest of you stoope to him.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: My lord, you may not thus disparage us,
Away I say with hatefull Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l:
And with the earle of
Kent
that favors him.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Nay, then lay violent hands upon your king,
Here Mortimer, sit thou in on Edwards throne,

Warwicke
and Lancaster, weare you my crowne,
Was ever king thus over rulde as I?

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: Learne then to rule us better and the realme.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: What we have done, our done, | our hart bloud shall maintaine.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: Think you that we can brooke this upstart upstart's pride?

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Anger and wrathfull furie stops stop my speech.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Why are you moov'd, be patient my good my lord,
And see what we your councellers have done.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: My lords, now let us all be resolute,
And either have our wils, or lose our lives.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Meete you for this, proud overdaring overbearing peeres ? ,
Ere my sweete Gaveston shall part from me,
This Ile shall fleete float upon the Ocean,
And wander to the unfrequented Inde Inde .

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: You know that I am legate to the Pope,
On your allegeance to the sea of Rome,
Subscribe as we have done to his exile.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Curse him, if he refuse, and then may we
Depose him and elect an other king.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: I there it goes, but yet I will not yeeld,
Curse me, depose me, doe the worst you can.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: Then linger not my lord but do it straight.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Remember how the Bishop was abusde,
Either banish him that was the cause thereof,
Or I will presentlie discharge these lords lord ,

Of dutie and allegeance due
to thee.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: It bootes me not to threat, I must speake faire,
The Legate of the Pope will be obayd:
My lord, you ye shalbe Chauncellor of the realme,
Thou Lancaster, high admirall of our the fleete,
Yong Mortimer and his unckle shalbe earles,
And you lord Warwick, president of the North,
And thou of Wales : , if this content you not,
Make severall kingdomes of this monarchie,
And share it equally amongst you all,
So I may have some nooke or corner left,
To frolike with my deerest Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Nothing shall alter us, wee are resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: Come, come, subscribe.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l:
Why should you love him,
whome the world hates so?

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Because he loves me more then all the world:
Ah none but rude and savage minded men,
Would seeke the ruine of my Gaveston,

You that be are
noble nobly borne should pitie him.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: You that are princely borne should shake him off,
For shame subscribe, and let the lowne depart.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: Urge him, my lord.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Are you content to banish him the realme?

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: I see I must, and therefore am content . ,
In steede of inke, ile write it with my teares.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: The king is love-sick for his minion.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Tis done, and now accursed hand fall off.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: Give it me, ile have it published in the streetes.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Ile see him presently dispatched away.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Now is my heart at ease.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: And so is mine.

sp.speaker: Penbrooke
sp.l: This will be good newes to the common sort.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: Be it or no, he shall not linger here.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: How fast they run to banish him I love,
They would not stir, were it to do me good:
Why should a king be subject to a priest?
Proud Rome, that hatchest such imperiall groomes,
For With these thy superstitious taperlights,
Wherewith thy antichristian churches blaze,
Ile fire thy crased buildings, and enforce
The Thy papall towers, to kisse the lowlie ground,
With slaughtered priests make may Tibers channell swell,
And bankes raisd raise rise higher with their sepulchers:
As for the peeres that backe the cleargie thus,
If I be king, not one of them shall live.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: My lord I heare it whispered every where,
That I am banishd, and must flie the land.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Tis true sweete Gaveston, oh were it were it false . ,
The Legate of the Pope will have it so,
And thou must hence, or I shall be deposd,
But I will raigne to be reveng'd of on them,
And therefore sweete friend, take it patiently,
Live where thou wilt, ile send thee gould enough,
And long thou shalt not stay, or if thou doost,
Ile come to thee, my love shall neare decline.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: Is all my hope turnd to this hell of greefe.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Rend not my hart with thy too piercing words,
Thou from this land, I from my selfe am banisht.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: To go from hence, greeves not poore Gaveston,
But to forsake you, in whose gratious lookes
The blessednes of Gaveston remaines,
For no where else seekes he felicitie.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: And onely this torments my wretched soule,
That whether whither I will or no thou must depart:

Be governour of
Ireland
in my stead,
And there abide till fortune call thee home.
Here take my picture, and let me weare thine,
O might I keepe thee heere, as I doe this,
Happie were I, but now most miserable.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: Tis something to be pitied of a king.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Thou shalt not hence, ile hide thee Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: I shal be found, and then twil greeve me more.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Kinde wordes, and mutuall talke, makes make our greefe greater,
Therefore with dum imbracement let us part.

Stay Gaveston ,
I cannot leave thee thus.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l:
For every looke, my lord love
,
drops downe a teare,
Seeing I must go, do not renew my sorrow.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: The time is little that thou hast to stay,
And therefore give me leave to looke my fill,
But come sweete friend, ile beare thee on thy way.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: The peeres will frowne.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: I passe not for their anger, come lets go,
O that we might as well returne as goe.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: whether whither goes my lord?

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Fawne not on me French strumpet, get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: On whom but on my husband should I fawne?

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: On Mortimer, with on whom ungentle Queen — ,
I say no more, judge you the rest my lord.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: In saying this, thou wrongst me Gaveston,
Ist not enough, that thou corrupts my lord,
And art a bawd to his affections,
But thou must call mine honor thus in question?

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: I meane not so, your grace must pardon me.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Thou art too familiar with that Mortimer,
And by thy meanes is Gaveston exilde . ,
But I would wish thee reconcile the lords,
Or thou shalt nere be reconcild to me.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Your highnes knowes, it lies not in my power.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Away then, touch me not, come Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Villaine, tis thou that robst me of my lord.

sp.speaker: Gaveston
sp.l: Madam, tis you thou that rob robs robb'st me of my lord.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Speake not unto her, let her droope and pine.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Wherein my lord, have I deservd these words?
Witnesse the teares that Isabella sheds,
Witnesse this hart, that sighing for thee breakes,
How deare my lord is to poore Isabell.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: And witnesse heaven how deere thou art to me.
There weepe, for till my Gaveston be repeald recalled ,
Assure thy selfe thou comst not in my sight.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: O miserable and distressed Queene!
Would when I left sweet France and was imbarkt,
That charming Circes Circe walking on the waves,
Had chaungd my shape, or at that the mariage day
The cup of Hymen had beene full of poyson,
Or with those armes that twind about my neck,
I had beene stifled, and not lived to see,
The king my lord thus to abandon me:
Like frantick Juno will I fill the earth,
With gastlie murmure of my sighes and cries,
For never doted Jove Jove doated on Ganimed,
So much as he on cursed Gaveston . ,
But that will more exasperate his wrath,
I must entreat him, I must speake him faire,
And be a meanes to call home Gaveston:
And yet heele ever dote on Gaveston,
And so am I for ever miserable.

div2.stage: Enter the Nobles to the Queene.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: Looke where the sister daughter of the king of Fraunce,
Sits wringing of her hands, and beats her brest.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l:
The king I feare hath sore
ill intreated ill-treated her.

sp.speaker: Penbrooke
sp.l: Hard is the hart, that injures injuries such a saint.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: I know tis long of Gaveston she weepes.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: Why? he is gone.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Madam, how fares your grace?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Ah Mortimer now breaks the kings hate forth,
And he confesseth that he loves me not.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Crie quittance Madam then, and love not him.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: No, rather will I die a thousand deaths,
And yet I love in vaine, heele nere love me.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: Feare ye you not Madam, now his minions gone,
His wanton humor will be quicklie left.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: O never Lancaster! I am injoynde,
To sue unto upon you all for his repeale:
This wils my lord, and this must I performe,
Or else be banisht from his highnesse presence.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: For his repeale, Madam ! , he comes not back,
Unlesse the sea cast up his shipwrack shipwrackt body.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: And to behold so sweete a sight as that,
Theres none here, but would run his horse to death.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: But madam, would you have us cal him home?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: I Mortimer, for till he be restorde,
The angrie king hath banished me the court:
And therefore as thou lovest and tendrest honourest me,
Be thou my advocate unto these upon the peeres.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l:
What, would ye
have me plead for Gaveston?

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l:
Plead for him he
that will, I am resolvde.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: And so am I my lord, diswade the Queene.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: O Lancaster, let him diswade the king,
For tis against my will he should returne

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: Then speake not for him, let the pesant go.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Tis for my selfe I speake, and not for him.

sp.speaker: Penbrooke
sp.l: No speaking will prevaile, and therefore cease.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Faire Queene forbeare to angle for the fish,
Which being caught, strikes him that takes it dead,
I meane that vile Torpedo, Gaveston,
That now I hope flotes on the Irish seas.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Sweete Mortimer, sit downe by me a while,
And I will tell thee reasons of such waighte,
As thou wilt soone subscribe to his repeale.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: It is impossible, but speake your minde.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Then thus, but none shal heare it but our selves.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l:
My Lords ,
albeit the Queen winne Mortimer,
W w ill you be resolute and hold with me?

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: Not I against my nephew.

sp.speaker: Penbrooke
sp.l: Feare not, the queens words cannot alter him.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: No ? , doe but marke how earnestly she pleads.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: And see how coldly his lookes make deniall.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: She smiles, now for my life his mind is changd.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: Ile rather loose his friendship I ay , then graunt.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Well of necessitie it must be so . ,
My Lords, that I abhorre base Gaveston,
I hope your honors make no question,
And therefore though I pleade for his repeall,
Tis not for his sake, but for our availe:

Nay ,
for the realms behoofe and for the kings.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: Fie Mortimer, dishonor not thy selfe,
Can this be true twas good to banish him , ?
And is this true good to call him home againe?
Such reasons make white blacke, and darke night day.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: My Lord of Lancaster, marke the respect.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: In no respect can contraries be true agree .

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Yet good my lord, heare what he can alledge.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: All that he speakes, is nothing, we are resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Do you not wish that Gaveston were dead?

sp.speaker: Penbrooke
sp.l: I would he were.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Why then my lord, give me but leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: But nephew, do not play the sophister.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: To mend the king, and do our countrie good:
Know you not Gaveston hath store of golde,

Which may in
Ireland
purchase him such friends,
As he will front the mightiest of us all,
And whereas he shall live and be belovde,
Tis hard for us to worke his overthrow.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: Marke you but that my lord of Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: But were he here, detested as he is,
How easilie might some base slave be subbornd,
To greet his lordship with a poniard,
And none so much as blame the murtherer murther ,
But rather praise him for that the brave attempt,
And in the Chronicle, enrowle his name,
For purging of the realme of such a plague.

sp.speaker: Penbrooke
sp.l: He saith true.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: I, but how chance this was not done before?

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Because my lords, it was not thought upon:
Nay more, when he shall know it lies in us,
To banish him, and then to call him home,
Twill make him vaile the topflag top flag top-flag of his pride,
And feare to offend the meanest noble man.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: But how if he do not Nephew?

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Then may we with some colour rise in armes,
For howsoever we have borne it out,
Tis treason to be up against the king . ,
So shall we we shall have the people of on our side,
Which for his fathers sake leane to the king,
But cannot brooke a night growne mushrump,
Such a one as my Lord of Cornewall is,
Should beare us downe down us of the nobilitie,
And when the commons and the nobles joyne,
Tis not the king can buckler Gaveston,
Weele pull him from the strongest hould he hath
My lords, if to performe this I be slack,
Thinke me as base a groome as Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: On that condition Lancaster will graunt.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: And so will Penbrooke and I I and Pembroke .

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: And Mortimer will rest at your commaund.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: And when this favour Isabell forgets,
Then let her live abandond and forlorne . ,
But see in happie time, my lord the king,
Having brought ta'en the Earle of Cornewall on his way,
Is new newsnow returnd, this newes will glad him much,
Yet not so much as me . , I love him more
Then he can Gaveston, would he lov'd love me
But halfe so much, then were I treble blest.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Hees gone, and for his absence thus I moorne,
Did never sorrow go so neere my heart,
As dooth the want of my sweete Gaveston,
And could my crownes revenew bring him back,
I would freelie give it to his enemies,
And thinke I gaind, having bought so deare a friend.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Harke how he harpes upon his minion.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: My heart is as an anvill unto sorrow,
Which beates upon it like the Cyclops hammers,
And with the noise turnes up my giddie braine,
And makes me frantick for my Gaveston:
Ah had some bloudlesse furie rose from hell,
And with my kinglie scepter stroke me dead,
When I was forst to leave my Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Lancaster.
sp.l:
Diablo, what passions call you these ?
.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: My gratious lord, I come to bring you newes.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: That you have parled with your Mortimer ju.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: That Gaveston , my Lord , shalbe repeald.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Repeald, the newes is too sweet to be true.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: But will you love me, if you finde it so?

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: If it be so, what will not Edward do?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: For Gaveston, but not for Isabell.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: For thee faire Queene, if thou lovest Gaveston,
Ile hang a golden tongue about thy my neck,
Seeing thou hast pleaded with so good successe.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: No other jewels hang about my neck
Then these my lord, nor let me have more wealth,
Then I may fetch from this ritch treasurie treasure :
O how a kisse revives poore Isabell.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Once more receive my hand, and let this be,
A second mariage twixt thy selfe and me.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: And may it proove more happie then the first . ,
My gentle lord, bespeake these nobles faire,
That waite attendance for a gratious looke,
And on their knees salute your majestie

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Couragious Lancaster, imbrace thy king,
And as grosse vapours perish by the sunne,
Even so let hatred with thy soveraignes soveraigne smile . ,
Live thou with me as my companion.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: This salutation overjoyes my heart.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Warwick , shalbe my chiefest counseller:
These silver haires will more adorne my court,
Then gaudie silkes, or rich imbrotherie . ,
Chide me sweete Warwick, if I go astray.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: Slay me my lord, when I offend your grace.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: In sollemne triumphes, and in publike showes,
Penbrooke shall beare the sword before the king.

sp.speaker: Penbrooke
sp.l: And with this sword, Penbrooke wil will Pembroke fight for you.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: But wherefore walkes yong Mortimer aside?
Be thou commaunder of our royall fleete,
Or if that loftie office like thee not,
I make thee heere lord Marshall of the realme.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: My lord, ile marshall so all your enemies,

As
England
shall be quiet, and you safe.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l:
And as for you, lord Mortimer of
England
,
Whose great atchivements in our forrain warre wars ,
DeservesDeserve no common place, nor or meane reward:
Be you the generall of the levied troopes,
That now are readie to assaile the Scots.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: In this your grace hath highly honoured me,
For with my nature warre doth best agree.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l:
Now is the king of
England
riche and strong,
Having the love of his renowned peeres.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: I Isabella nere was my heart so light . ,
Clarke of the crowne, direct our warrant forth,
For Gaveston to Ireland: Beamont flie,
As fast as Iris, or Joves Mercurie.

sp.speaker: Beamont
sp.l: It shalbe done my gratious Lord.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Lord Mortimer, we leave you to your charge:
Now let us in, and feast it roiallie:
Against our friend the earle of Cornewall comes,
Weele have a generall tilt and turnament,
And then his mariage shalbe solemnized,
For wot wote wrote you not that I have made him sure,

Unto our your cosin, the earle of
Glosters
heire.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: Such newes we heare my lord.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: That day, if not for him , . yet for my sake,

Who in the
triumphe will be challenger,
Spare for no cost, we will requite your love.

sp.speaker: Warwicke
sp.l: In this, or ought, your highnes shall commaund us.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Thankes gentle Warwick, come lets in and revell.

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: Nephue, I must to Scotland, thou staiest here . ,
Leave now to oppose thy selfe against the king,
Thou seest by nature he is milde and calme,
And seeing his minde so dotes on Gaveston,
Let him without controulement have his will . ,
The mightiest kings have had their minions,
Great Alexander lovde Ephestion,

The conquering Hercules Hector,
for did for for his Hilas wept weepe ,
And for Patroclus sterne Achillis droopt:
And not kings onelie, but the wisest men,
The Romaine Tullie loved wit="Q3">Octavius Octavis ,
Grave Socrates, wilde Alcibiades:
Then let his grace, whose youth is flexible,
And promiseth as much as we can wish,
Freely enjoy that vaine light-headed earle,
For riper yeares will weane him from such toyes.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Unckle, his wanton humor greeves not me,
But this I scorne, that one so baselie borne,
Should by his soveraignes favour grow so pert,

And riote it
with the treasure of the realme,
While souldiers mutinie for want of paie.
He weares a lords revenewe on his back,
And Midas like he jets it in the court,
With base outlandish cullions at his heeles,
Whose proud fantastick liveries make makes such show,
As if that Proteus god of shapes appearde . ,
I have not seene a dapper jack so briske,
He weares a short Italian hooded cloake,
Larded with pearle, and in his tuskan cap
A jewell of more value then the crowne . ,
Whiles other others walke below, the king and he
From out a window, laugh at such as we,
And floute our traine, and jest jet at our attire:

Unckle, tis this that
makes me impatient so impatient .

sp.speaker: Mortimer senior
sp.l: But nephew, now you see the king is changd.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Then so am I, and live to do him service,
But whiles I have a sword, a hand, a hart,
I will not yeeld to any such upstart.
You know my minde, come unckle lets away.

div2.head: Act Two, Scene One

sp.speaker: Baldock.
sp.l:
Seeing that our Lord th'earle of
Glosters
dead,
Which of the nobles dost thou meane to serve?

sp.speaker: Spencer
sp.l: Not Mortimer, nor any of his side,
Because the king and he are enemies . ,
Baldock: learne this of me, a factious lord
Shall hardly do himselfe good, much lesse us,
But he that hath the favour of a king,
May with one word, advaunce us while we live:
The liberall earle of Cornewall is the man,
On whose good fortune Spencers hope depends.

sp.speaker: Baldock
sp.l: What, meane you then to be his follower?

sp.speaker: Spencer
sp.l: No, his companion, for he loves me well,
And would have once preferd me to the king.

sp.speaker: Baldock
sp.l: But he is banisht, theres small hope of him.

sp.speaker: Spencer
sp.l: I for a while, but Baldock marke the end,
A friend of mine told me in secrecie,
That hees repeald recalled , and sent for back againe,
And even now, a poast came from the court,
With letters to our ladie from the King,
And as she red, she smild, which makes me thinke,
It is about her lover Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Baldock
sp.l: Tis like enough, for since he was exild,
She neither walkes abroad, nor comes in sight:
But I had thought the match had beene broke off,
And that his banishment had changd her minde.

sp.speaker: Spencer
sp.l: Our Ladies first love is not wavering,
My life for thine she will have Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Baldock
sp.l: Then hope I by her meanes to be preferd,
Having read unto her since she I was a childe.

sp.speaker: Spencer
sp.l: Then Balduck, you must cast the scholler off,
And learne to court it like a Gentleman,
Tis not a black coate and a little band,
A Velvet cap'de cloake, fac'st before with Serge,
And smelling to a Nosegay all the day,
Or holding of a napkin in your hand,
Or saying a long grace at a tables end,
Or making lowe legs to a noble man,
Or looking downeward, with your eye lids close,
And saying, trulie ant may please your honor,
Can get you any favour with great men . ,
You must be proud, bold, pleasant, resolute,
And now and then, stab as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Baldock
sp.l:
Spencer, thou knowest I hate such formall
toies,
And use them but of as meere hypocrisie.
Mine old lord whiles he livde, was so precise,
That he would take exceptions exception at my buttons,
And being like pins heads, blame me for the their bignesse,
Which made me curate-like in mine attire,
Though inwardly licentious enough,
And apt for any kinde of villanie.
I am none of these those common pedants pendants I,
That cannot speake without propterea quod.

sp.speaker: Spencer
sp.l: But one of those that saith quandoquidem quando quidem ,
And hath a speciall gift to forme a verbe.

sp.speaker: Baldock
sp.l: Leave of this jesting, here my lady comes.

div2.stage: Enter the Ladie (Neece to the king).

sp.l: The greefe for his exile was not so much,
As is the joy of his returning home . ,
This letter came from my sweete Gaveston,

What needst thou ,
love, thus to excuse thy selfe?
I know thou couldst not come and visit me . ,

l.quote: I will not long be from thee though I die:

sp.l: This argues the entire love of my Lord . ,

l.quote: When I forsake thee, death seaze on my heart,

sp.l:
But rest
stay Q3-4, Dd2-
I put thee here where Gaveston shall sleepe
Now to the letter of my Lord the King,
He wils me to repaire unto the court,
And meete my Gaveston why do I stay,
Seeing that he talkes thus of my mariage day?
Whose there, Balduck?
See that my coache be readie, I must hence.

sp.speaker: Baldock
sp.l: It shall be done madam.

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: And meete me at the parke pale -pail presentlie:
Spencer, stay you and beare me companie,
For I have joyfull newes to tell thee of;
My lord of Cornewall is a comming over,
And will be at the court as soone as we.

sp.speaker: Spencer
sp.l: I knew the King would have him home againe.

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: If all things sort out, as I hope they will,
Thy service Spencer shalbe thought upon.

sp.speaker: Spencer
sp.l: I humbly thanke your Ladieship.

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: Come lead the way, I long till I am there.

div2.head: Act Two, Scene Two
div2.stage:
Enter Edward, the Queene, Lancaster, Mortimer[junior],
Warwicke
, Penbrooke,
Kent
, attendants.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: The winde is good, I wonder why he stayes,
I feare me he is wrackt upon the sea.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Look Lancaster how passionate he is,
And still his minde runs on his minion.

sp.speaker: Lancaster
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: How now, what newes, is Gaveston arrivde?

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.

sp.l: And thus, most humbly do we take our out leave.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Farewell, I know the next newes that they bring,
Will be my death, and welcome shall it be,
To wretched men death is felicitie.

sp.speaker: Leister
sp.l: An other poast, what newes bringes he?

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Such newes as I expect, come Bartley, come,
And tell thy message to my naked brest.

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.l: My lord, thinke not a thought so villanous
Can harbor in a man of noble birth.
To do your highnes service and devoire,

And save you from your foes, would
Bartley Berkley
would
die.

sp.speaker: Leister
sp.l: My lorde, the counsell of and the Queene commaunds command ,
That I resigne my charge.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: And who must keepe mee now, must you my lorde?

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.l: I, my most gratious lord, so tis decreed.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: By Mortimer, whose name is written here,
Well may I rent his name, that rends my hart . ,
This poore revenge hath something easd my minde,
So may his limmes be torne, as is this paper,
Heare me immortall immorrall Jove, and graunt it too.

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.l: Your grace must hence with mee to Bartley straight.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: whether whither you will, all places are alike,
And every earth is fit for buriall.

sp.speaker: Leister
sp.l: Favor him my lord, as much as lieth in you.

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.l: Even so betide my soule as I use him.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Mine My enemie hath pitied my estate,
And thats the cause that I am now remoovde.

sp.speaker: Bartley
sp.l: And thinkes your grace that Bartley will bee cruell?

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: I know not, but of this am I I am assured,
That death ends all, and I can die but once . ,
Leicester, farewell.
Not yet my lorde, ile beare you on your waye.

div2.head: Act Five, Scene Two

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Faire Isabell now have we our desire,
The proud corrupters of the light-brainde king,
Have done their homage to the loftie gallowes,
And he himselfe lies in captivitie . ,
Be rulde by me, and we will rule the realme,
In any case, take heed of childish feare,
For now we hould an old Wolfe by the eares eare ,
That if he slip will seaze upon us both,
And gripe the sorer being gript himselfe . ,
Thinke therefore madam that it imports us as much,
To erect elect your sonne with all withall the speed we may,
And that I be protector over him,
For our behoofe will twill beare the greater sway
When as that a kings name shall be under writ.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Sweet Mortimer, the life of Isabell
Be thou perswaded, that I love thee well,
And therefore so the prince my sonne be safe,
Whome I esteeme as deare as these mine eyes,
Conclude against his father what thou wilt,
And I my selfe will willinglie subscribe.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l:
First would I heare newes the news
that
hee were deposde,
And then let me alone to handle him.
sp.stage: Enter Messenger [and then Bishop of Winchester with the crown].
sp.l: Mor.ju. Letters from whence ?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: From Killingworth my lorde.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: How fares my lord the king ?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: In health madam, but full of pensivenes.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Alas poore soule, would I could ease his greefe . ,
Thankes gentle Winchester : , sirra, be gon.
The king hath willingly resignde his crowne.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: O happie newes, send for the prince my sonne.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l:
Further, or this letter
was sealed, Lord Bartley came,
So that he now is gone from Killingworth,
And we have heard that Edmund laid a plot,
To set his brother free, no more but so . ,

The lord Mortimer. The Lord of Bartley is so as as
pitifull,
As Leicester Leicester that had charge of him before.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Then let some other be his guardian.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Let me alone, here is the privie seale,
Whose there ? , call hither Gurney and Matrevis . ,
To dash the heavie headed Edmunds drift,
Bartley shall be dischargd, the king remoovde,
And none but we shall know where he lieth doth lie .

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: But Mortimer, as long as he survives
What safetie rests for us, or for my sonne?

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l:
Speake, shall he presently be dispatch'd and die
?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I would hee were, so it ere not by my meanes.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Inough .
Matrevis, write a letter presently
Unto the Lord of Bartley from our selfe,
That he resigne the king to thee and Gurney,
And when tis done, we will subscribe our name.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: It shall be done my lord.

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l: My Lorde.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: As thou intendest to rise by Mortimer,
Who now makes Fortunes wheele turne as he please,
Seeke all the meanes thou canst to make him droope,
And neither give him kinde word, nor good looke.

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l: I warrant you my lord.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l:
And this above the rest, because we
heare
That Edmund casts to worke his libertie,
Remoove him still from place to place by night,
Till And at the last, he be come to Killingworth,
And then from thence to Bartley Bartley back againe:
And by the way to make him fret the more,
Speake curstlie to him, and in any case
Let no man comfort him, if he chaunce to weepe,
But amplifie his greefe with bitter words.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: Feare not my Lord, weele do as you commaund.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: So now away, post thither wards amaine.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Whither goes this letter, to my lord the king?
Commend me humblie to his Majestie,
And tell him, that I labour all in vaine,
To ease his greefe, and worke his libertie:
And beare him this, as witnesse of my love.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: I will madam.

div2.stage: Exeunt Matrevis and Gurney. Manent Isabell and Mortimer.
Enter the yong Prince, and the Earle of Kent talking with him.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Finely dissembled, do so still sweet Queene . ,
Heere comes the yong prince, with the Earle of Kent.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Some thing he whispers in his childish eares.

sp.speaker: Mortimer.
sp.l: If he have such accesse unto the prince,
Our plots and stratagems will soone be dasht.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Use Edmund friendly, as if all were well.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: How fares my honorable lord of Kent?
In health sweete Mortimer, how fares your grace ? . ,

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Well, if my Lorde your brother were enlargde.
I heare of late he hath deposde himselfe.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: The more my greefe.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: And mine.
Ah they how they do dissemble.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Sweete sonne come hither, I must talke with thee.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Thou You being his unckle, and the next of bloud,
Doe looke to be protector over the prince ? .
Not I my lord: who should protect the sonne,
But she that gave him life, I meane the Queene?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Mother, perswade me not to weare the crowne,
Let him be king, I am too yong to raigne.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: But bee content, seeing it it is Q3-4, Dd2- 'tis his highnesse pleasure.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Let me but see him first, and then I will.

I ,
do sweete Nephew.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Brother, you know it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Why, is he dead ?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: No, God forbid.
I would those wordes proceeded from your heart.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Inconstant Edmund, doost thou favor him,
That wast a cause of his imprisonment?
The more cause have I now to make amends.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: I tell thee tis not meet, that one so false
Should come about the person of a prince . ,
My lord, he hath betraied the king his brother,
And therefore trust him not.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: But hee repents, and sorrowes for it now.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Come sonne, and go with this gentle Lorde and me.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: With you I will, but not with Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Why yongling, s'dainst dain'st disdain'st thou so of Mortimer?
Then I will carrie thee by force away.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Helpe unckle Kent, Mortimer will wrong me.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Brother Edmund, strive not, we are his friends,
Isabell is neerer then the earle of Kent.
Sister, Edward is my charge, redeeme release him.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Edward is my sonne, and I will keepe him. [Is going off]

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Mortimer shall know that he hath wrongde mee.
Hence will I haste to Killingworth castle,
And rescue aged Edward from his foes,
To be revengde on Mortimer and thee.

div2.head: Act Five, Scene Three
div2.stage: Enter Matrevis and Gurney with the King [and souldiers].

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: My lord, be not pensive, we are your friends . ,
Men are ordaind to live in miserie,
Therefore come, dalliance dangereth endangereth our lives.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Friends, whither must unhappie Edward go,
Will hatefull Mortimer appoint no rest?
Must I be vexed like the nightly birde,
Whose sight is loathsome to all winged fowles?
When will the furie of his minde asswage?
When will his hart be satisfied with bloud ?
If mine will serve, unbowell straight this brest,
And give my heart to Isabell and him,
It is the chiefest marke they levell at.

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l: Not so my liege, the Queene hath given this us charge,
To Only to Only to keepe your grace in safetie,

Your passions make your dolours choler
to
increase.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: This usage makes my miserie increase to increase .
But can my ayre of life continue long,
When all my sences are anoyde with stenche?
Within a dungeon Englands king is kept,
Where I am sterv'd for want of sustenance,
My daily diet, is heart breaking sobs,
That almost rents rend the closet of my heart,
Thus lives old Edward not reliev'd by any,
And so must die, though pitied by many.
O water gentle friends to coole my thirst,
And cleare my bodie from foule excrements.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: Heeres channell water, as our your charge is given . ,
Sit downe, for weele be Barbars to your grace.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Traitors away, what will you murther me,
Or choake your soveraigne with puddle water?

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l: No, but wash your face, and shave away your beard,
Least you be knowne, and so be rescued.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l:
Why strive you thus ? ,
your labour is in vaine . ?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: The Wrenne may strive against the Lions strength , .
But all in vaine, so vainely do I strive,
To seeke for mercie at a tyrants hand.
sp.stage: They wash him with puddle water, and shave his beard away.
sp.l: Immortall powers, that knowes know the painfull cares,
That waites wait upon my poore distressed soule,

O
levell all , , your lookes upon these daring men,
That wronges wrong their liege and soveraigne, Englands king . ,

O Gaveston , it is for thee that
I am wrongd,
For me, both, both the Spencers died,
And for your sakes, a thousand wrongest ile take,
The Spencers ghostes, where ever they remaine,

Wish well to mine, then tush ,
for them ile die.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: Twixt theirs and yours, shall be no enmitie . ,
Come, come, away, now put the torches out,
Weele enter in by darkenes to into Killingworth.

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l: How now, who comes there here ?

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: Guarde the king sure, it is the earle of Kent.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: O gentle brother, helpe to rescue me.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: Keepe them a sunder, thrust in the king.
Souldiers, let me but talke to him one worde.

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l: Lay hands upon the earle for this his O2-4, Dd2- assault.

Lay downe your weapons, traitors ,
yeeld the king.
Matrevis. Edmund, yeeld thou thy self, or thou shalt die.
Base villaines, wherefore doe you gripe mee thus ?

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l:
Binde Blind him, and so
convey him to the court.
Where is the court but heere, heere is the king,
And I will visit him, why stay you me?

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: The court is where lord Mortimer remaines,
Thither shall your honour go, and so farewell.

div2.stage: Exeunt Matrevis and Gurney, with the king.

sp.l: O miserable is that commonweale,
Where lords keepe courts, and kings are lockt in prison!

sp.speaker: Souldier.
sp.l: Wherefore stay we? on sirs to the court.
I, lead me whether whither you will, even to my death,
Seeing that my brother cannot be releast.

div2.head: Act Five, Scene Four

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: The king must die, or Mortimer goes downe,
The commons now begin to pitie him,
Yet he that is the cause of Edwards death,
Is sure to pay for it when his sonne is of age,
And therefore will I do it cunninglie . ,
This letter written by a friend of ours,
Containes his death, yet bids them save his life.

l.name: Edwardum occidere nolite timere bonum est.

sp.l: Feare not to kill the king tis good he die.
But read it thus, and thats an other sence:

l.name: Edwardum occidere nolite timere bonum est.

sp.l: Kill not the king tis good to feare the worst.
Unpointed as it is, thus shall it goe,
That being dead, if it chaunce to be found,
Matrevis and the rest may beare the blame,
And we be quit that causde it to be done:
Within this roome is lockt the messenger,
That shall conveie it, and performe the rest,
And by a secret token that he beares,
Shall he be murdered when the deed is done.
Lightborn, Come forth.
Art thou as so resolute as thou wast ?

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: What else my lord ? and nay farre more resolute.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: And hast thou cast how to accomplish it?

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: I, I, and none shall know which way he died.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: But at his lookes Lightborne thou wilt relent.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: Relent, ha, ha, I use much to relent.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Well, do it bravely, and be secret.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: You shall not need to give instructions,
Tis not the first time I have killed a man . ,
I learnde in Naples how to poison flowers,
To strangle with a lawne thrust through downe the throte,
To pierce the wind-pipe with a the needles point,
Or whilst one is a sleepe, to take a quill
And blowe a little powder in his eares,
Or open his mouth, and powre quick silver downe,
But And yet I have a braver way then these.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Whats that?

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: Nay, you shall pardon me, none shall knowe my trickes.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: I care not how it is, so it be not spide : ,
Deliver this to Gurney and Matrevis,
At every ten miles mile Q2-3, Dd1- end thou hast a horse.
Take this, away, and never see me more.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: No ? .

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: No,
Unlesse thou bring bring'st me newes of Edwards death.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: That will I quicklie do farewell my lord.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l:
The prince I rule, the queene do I I do
commaund mand ,
And with a lowly conge to the ground,
The proudest lords salute me as I passe,
I seale, I cancell, I do what I will,
Feard am I more then lov'd, let me be feard,
And when I frowne, make all the court looke pale,
I view the prince with Aristarchus Aristarcus Aristorchus eyes,
Whose lookes were as a breeching to a boye . ,
They thrust upon me the Protectorship,
And sue to me for that that that which I desire,
While at the councell table, grave enough,
And not unlike a bashfull puretaine paretaine ,
First I complaine of imbecilitie,
Saying it is, onus quam gravissimum,
Till being interrupted by my friends,
Suscepi that provinciam as they terme it,
And to conclude, I am Protector now,
Now is all all is sure, the Queene and Mortimer
Shall rule the realme, the king and king , and none rule us rules us ,
Mine enemies will I plague, my friends advance,
And what I list commaund, who dare controwle ? ,

l.name: Major sum quam cui possitfortuna nocere . ,

sp.l: And that this be the coronation day,
It pleaseth me, and Isabell the Queene . ,
The trumpets sound, I must go take my place.

div2.stage:
Enter the yong King, [Arch]bishop [of
Canterbury Winchester ], Champion, Nobles, Queene.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Long live king Edward, by the grace of God
King of England, and lorde of Ireland.

sp.speaker: Champion
sp.l: If any Christian, Heathen, Turke, or Jew,
Dares Dare but affirme, that Edwards not true king,
And will avouche his saying with the sworde,
I am the Champion that will combate him ! ? .

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: None comes, sound trumpets.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Champion, heeres to thee.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Lord Mortimer, now take him to your charge.

div2.stage: Enter Souldiers with the Earle of Kent prisoner.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: What traitor have wee there with blades and billes?

sp.speaker: Souldier.
sp.l: Edmund the Earle of Kent.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What hath he done?

sp.speaker: Souldier
sp.l: A He Dd1- would have taken the king away perforce,
As we were bringing him to Killingworth.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Did you attempt his rescue, Edmund speake?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Mortimer, I did, he is our king,
And thou compelst this the prince to weare the crowne.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Strike off his head, he shall have marshall lawe.
Strike of my head ? , base traitor I defie thee.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My lord, he is my unckle, and shall live.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: My lord, he is your enemie, and shall die.
Staie villaines.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sweete mother, if I cannot pardon him,
Intreate my lord Protector for his life.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Sonne, be content, I dare not speake a worde.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Nor I, and yet me thinkes I should commaund,
But seeing I cannot, ile entreate for him:
My lord, if you will let my unckle live,
I will requite it when I come to age.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Tis for your highnesse good, and for the realmes . ,
How often shall I bid you beare him hence? [To Souldiers.]
Art thou king a king , must I die at thy commaund?

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: At our commaund, once more away with him.
Let me but stay and speake, I will not go,
Either my brother or his sonne is king,

And none neither of both
,
them then thirst for Edmunds bloud.
And therefore soldiers whether whither will you hale me?

div2.stage: They hale Edmund away, and carie him to be beheaded.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What safetie may I looke for at his hands,
If that my Unckle shall be murthered thus?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Feare not sweete boye, ile garde thee from thy foes,
Had Edmund liv'de, he would have sought thy death . ,
Come sonne, weele ride a hunting in the parke.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And shall my Unckle Edmund ride with us?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: He is a traitor, thinke not on him, come.

div2.head: Act Five, Scene Five

sp.speaker: Matrevis.
sp.l: Gurney, I wonder the king dies not,
Being in a vault up to the knees in water,

To which the channels of the castell Bastell castles
runne runs ,
From whence a dampe continually ariseth,
That were enough to poison any man,
Much more a king brought up so tenderlie.

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l: And so do I, Matrevis: yesternight
I opened but the doore to throw him meate,
And I was almost stifeled wit the savor.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: He hath a body able to endure,
More then we can enflict, and therefore now,
Let us assaile his minde another while.

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l: Send for him out thence, and I will anger him.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: But stay, whose this ?

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: My lord protector greetes you.

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l: Whats heere ? I know not how to conster construe it.

sp.speaker: Matrevis.
sp.l: Gurney, it was left unpointed for the nonce,
Thats his meaning.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: Know you ye this token ? , I must have the king . ?

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l:
I ,
stay a while, thou shalt have answer straight.
This villain's sent to make away the king.

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l: I thought as much.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: And when the murders done,
See how he must be handled for his labour,
Pereat iste: let him have the king,

What else ? ,
Heere is heere is heer's the keyes key , this is the lake lock lock ,
Doe as you are commaunded by my lord.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: I know what I must do, get you away,
Yet be not farre off,
I shall need your helpe,

See that
in the next roome room
that I have a fier,

And
get me a spit spet , and let it be red hote.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l: Neede you any thing besides?

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l:
What else,
a table and a fetherbed.

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l: Thats all ? .

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l:
I, I, so :
when I call you thou Q2-4, Dd1- , bring it in.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: Feare not you that.

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l:
Heeres a light to
go into the dungeon.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: So,
Now must I about this geare, nere was there any
So finely handled as this king shalbe . ,
Foh, heeres a place in deed with all my hart.

div2.stage: [Edward comes com'st up or is discovered.]

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Whose there, what light is that, wherefore comes thou?

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: To comfort you, and bring you joyfull newes.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Small comfort findes poore Edward in thy lookes,
Villaine, I know thou comst to murther me.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: To murther you my most gratious lorde ? ,
Farre is it from my hart to do you harme,
The Queene sent me, to see how you were used,
For she relents at this your miserie.
And what eyes can refraine from shedding teares,
To see a king in this most pittious state?

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Weepst thou already ? , list a while to me,
And then thy heart, were it as Gurneys is,
Or as Matrevis, hewne from the Caucasus,
Yet will it melt, ere I have done my tale . ,
This dungeon where they keepe me, is the sincke,
Wherein the filthe of all the castell falles.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: O villaines!

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: And there in mire and puddle have I stood,
This ten dayes day' space, and least that I should sleepe,
One plaies continually upon a Drum,
They give me bread and water being a king,
So that for want of sleepe and sustenance,
My mindes distempered, and my bodies numde,
And whether whither I have limmes or no, I know not . ,
O would my bloud dropt drop out from every vaine,
As doth this water from my tattered robes:
Tell Isabell the Queene, I lookt not thus,
When for her sake I ran at tilt in Fraunce,
And there unhorste the duke of Cleremont.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: O speake no more my lorde, this breakes my heart.
Lie on this bed, and rest your selfe a while . ,

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: These lookes of thine can harbor nought but death.
I see my tragedie written in thy browes,
Yet stay a while, forbeare thy bloudie hande,
And let me see the stroke before it comes,
That and even then when I shall lose my life,
My minde may be more stedfast on my God.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: What meanes mean'st Q2, Dd1- your highnesse to mistrust me thus ?

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: What meanes thou to dissemble with me thus ?

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: These handes were never stainde with innocent bloud,
Nor shall they now be tainted with a kings.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Forgive my thought me then , for having such a thought,
One jewell have I left, receive thou this . ,
Still feare I, and I know not whats the cause,
But everie jointe shakes as I give it thee:
O if thou harborst murther in thy hart,
Let this gift change thy minde, and save thy soule,
Know that I am a king, oh at that name,
I feele a hell of greefe : , where is my crowne?

Gone, gone, and doe I still yet
remaine remain
alive
?

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: Your overwatchde my lord, lie downe and rest.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: But that greefe keepes me waking, I shoulde sleepe,
For not these ten daies have these eyes lids eye-lids closd . ,
Now as I speake they fall, and yet with feare
Open againe . , O wherefore sits thou heare?

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: If you mistrust me, ile be gon my lord.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: No, no, for if thou meanst to murther me,
Thou wilt returne againe, and therefore stay.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: He sleepes.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l:
O let me not die , yet ,
stay,
O stay a while.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: How now my Lorde.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Something still busseth in mine eares,
And tels me, if I sleepe I never ne'er shall wake,
This feare is that which makes me tremble thus,
And therefore tell me, wherefore art thou come?

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: To rid thee of thy life . , Matrevis come . ,

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: I am too weake and feeble to resist,
Assist me sweete God, and receive my soule.

div2.stage: [Enter Matrevis, Gurney, and exeunt. Return with table.]

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: Runne for the table.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: O spare me, or dispatche me in a trice.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: So, lay the table downe, and stampe on it,
But not too hard, least that you thou bruse his body.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: I feare mee that this crie will raise the towne,
And therefore let us take horse and away.

sp.speaker: Lightborne
sp.l: Tell me sirs, was it is not bravelie done?

sp.speaker: Gurney
sp.l: Excellent well, take this for thy rewarde.
Come let us cast the body in the mote,
And beare the kings news to Mortimer our lord,
Away.

div2.head: Act Five, Scene Six
div2.stage: Enter Mortimer and Matrevis [at different doors].

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Ist done, Matrevis, and the murtherer dead?

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: I my good Lord, I would it were undone.

sp.speaker: Mortimer.
sp.l:
Matrevis, if thou now
growest penitent
Ile be thy ghostly father, therefore choose,
whether whither thou wilt be secret in this,
Or else die by the hand of Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l:
Gurney ,
my lord ,
is fled, and will I feare,
Betray us both, therefore let me flie.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Flie to the Savages.

sp.speaker: Matrevis
sp.l: I humblie thanke your honour.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: As for my selfe, I stand as Joves huge tree,
And others are but shrubs compard to me,
All tremble at my name, and I feare none,
Lets see who dare impeache me for his death ?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: A Oh Mortimer, the king my sonne hath news,
His fathers dead, and we have murdered him.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: What if he have? the king is yet a childe.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: I, I Ay I , but he teares his haire, and wrings his handes,
And vowes to be revengd upon us both,
Into the councell chamber he is gone,
To crave the aide and succour of his peeres . ,
Aye Ah Dd1- me, see where he comes, and they with him,
Now Mortimer begins our tragedie.

div2.stage: Enter the King, with the lords.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord
sp.l: Feare not my lord, know that you are a king.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Villaine.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: How Ho now my lord ?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thinke not that I am frighted frightened with thy words,
My father's murdered through thy treacherie,
And thou shalt die, and on his mournefull hearse,
Thy hatefull and accursed head shall lie,
To witnesse to the world, that by thy meanes,
His kingly body was too so soone interrde.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Weepe not sweete sonne.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Forbid not me me not to weepe, he was my father,
And had you lov'de him halfe so well as I,
You could not beare his death thus patiently,
But you I feare, conspirde with Mortimer.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord
sp.l: Why speake you not unto my lord the king?

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Because I thinke think it think it scorne to be be so accusde,
Who is the man dare dares Q2-4, Dd1- say I murdered murthered murderedd him?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Traitor, in me my loving father speakes,
And plainely saith, twas thou that murdredst murdrest murdered him.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: But hath your grace no other proofe then this ?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Yes, if this be the hand of Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: False Gurney hath betraide me and himselfe.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: I feard as much, murther cannot be hid.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Tis It is my hand, what gather you by this.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: That thither thou didst send a murtherer.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: What murtherer? bring foorth the man I sent.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: A Aye Mortimer, thou knowest that he is slaine,
And so shalt thou be too: why staies he heere?
Bring him unto a hurdle, drag him foorth,
Hang him I say, and set his quarters up,
But bring his head back presently to me.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: For my sake sweete sonne Sweet son, for my sake pittie Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Madam, intreat not, I will rather die,
Then sue for life unto a paltrie boye.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Hence with the traitor, with the murderer.

sp.speaker: Mortimer ju.
sp.l: Base fortune, now I see, that in thy wheele
There is a point, to which when men aspire,
They tumble hedlong downe : , that point I touchte,
And seeing there was no place to mount up higher,
Why should I greeve at my declining fall ? ,
Farewell faire Queene, weepe not for Mortimer,
That scornes the world, and as a traveller,
Goes to discover countries yet unknowne.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What, suffer you the traitor to delay?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: As thou receivedst thy life from me,
Spill not the bloud of gentle Mortimer.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: This argues, that you spilt my fathers bloud,
Els would you not intreate for Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l:
I spill his bloud ? no
.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l:
I ,
madam ,
you, for so the rumor runnes.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: That rumor is untrue, for loving thee,
Is this report raisde on poore Isabell.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I doe not thinke her so unnaturall.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord
sp.l: My lord, I feare me it will proove too true.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Mother, you are suspected for his death,
And therefore we commit you to the Tower,

Till further triall may
be made thereof . ,
If you be guiltie, though I be your sonne,
Thinke not to finde me slack or pitifull.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Nay, to my death, for too long have I lived,
When as my sonne thinkes to abridge my daies.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Awaye with her, her wordes inforce these teares,
And I shall pitie her if she speake againe.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Shall I not moorne for my beloved lord , ?
And with the rest accompanie him to his the grave ? .

sp.speaker: 2. Lord
sp.l: Thus Tush madam, tis the kings will you shall hence.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: He hath forgotten me, stay, I am his mother.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord
sp.l: That bootes not, therefore gentle madam goe.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Then come sweete death, and rid me of this greefe.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Goe fetche my fathers hearse, where it shall lie,
And bring my funerall robes: accursed head,
Could I have rulde thee then, as I do now,
Thou hadst not hatcht this monstrous treacherie ! ? .

my lords:
